g_inverse_matrix.cpp

Calculates the generalized inverse matrix of input matrix "amatA". Given an input matrix this function uses singular value decomposition to determine the generalized inverse matrix , so that

If is singular, i.e. or is non-square then is not unique.

Parameters:
amatA  input matrix.
bmatA  generalized inverse matrix.
Returns:
none.
Please follow the link to view the source code of the example. The example can be executed in the example directory of package LinAlg.

Author:
M. Kreutz
Date:
1998
Changes
none
Status
stable
See also:
svd.cpp

00053 #include<iostream>
00054 #include "Array/ArrayIo.h"
00055 #include "LinAlg/linalg.h"
00056 
00057 using namespace std;
00058 
00059 
00060 // Values used for initialization of input matrix:
00061 double values[ 9 ] = {
00062     1., 2., -1.,
00063     2., 5., -1.,
00064     1., 2.,  0.
00065 
00066 };
00067 
00068 
00069 int main()
00070 {
00071     unsigned          i, j;      // Counter variables.
00072     Array2D< double > A( 3, 3 ), // Input matrix.
00073                       B( 3, 3 ); // Generalized inverse matrix.
00074 
00075 
00076     // Initialize matrices:
00077     for ( i = 0; i < 3; i++ )
00078     {
00079         for ( j = 0; j < 3; j++ )
00080         {
00081             A( i, j ) = values[ i * 3 + j ];
00082         }
00083     }
00084     B = .0;
00085 
00086     // Output of input matrix:
00087     cout << "input matrix:" << endl;
00088     writeArray( A, cout );
00089 
00090     // Calculate generalized inverse matrix:
00091     g_inverse( A, B );
00092 
00093     // Output of generalized inverse matrix:
00094     cout << "generalized inverse matrix:" << endl;
00095     writeArray( B, cout );
00096 
00097     return 0;
00098 }
